thread.title_full: Why men should forget tired old pick-up lines and try a good punchline | afr.com

author: Jill Margo
title: Why men should forget tired old pick-up lines and try a good punchline
text:
Laughing at this jokes is a good sign; even better is if a couple laugh together. by Jill Margo A man with romance on his mind may find a punchline is more effective than a pick-up line.
New research shows the more times he tries to be funny and the more she laughs at his attempts, the more likely she's interested in dating.
An even better indicator of potential romantic connection is if the two laugh together.
Jeffrey Hall, associate professor of communication studies at the University of Kansas, is an authority on flirting.
His latest findings are published in the journal Evolutionary Psychology .
Since early this century, researchers have debated whether women value a sense of humour because it indicates intelligence in a potential mate.
Darwin's sexual selection theory holds that because the cost of reproduction is heavier for women, their reproductive span is short and they can have fewer children then men, they are choosier when it comes to selecting a mate.
The pressure is on the male to impress a potential mate.
 High-status men naturally have a high index of attraction because of their perceived ability to support a woman and her offspring.
The theory goes that intelligence is also a highly desirable trait because it raises the likelihood he will acquire status or resources.
Eons ago, this was equivalent to mating with a skilled hunter.
Witty and wise Humour requires an appreciation of subtlety, an ability to use juxtaposition, good timing, and emotional and social intelligence.
And as it can't be faked, it's seen as an indicator of mental fitness.
But humour is about more than just intelligence, says Hall, who has written 40 articles and book chapters on humour in relationships and is a recognised expert on flirting styles.
His latest work shows men with a sense of humour are desirable in social gatherings and as mates.
Their humour indicates an attractive social disposition and possibly a warm, extroverted character, which augurs well for the future.
He argues that for women humour is perceived as marker for extroversion rather than intelligence.
Men use it to gauge a woman's interest; to get her to show her cards. For some, it is a conscious strategy.
He says when men make jokes and women laugh, they may be performing a script in courtship.
Previous studies have suggested women's brains show greater activity than men's in reward-related regions in response to humour.
This suggests women are genetically hardwired to find a sense of humour attractive.
